claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination broadens tumor antigen presentation, including expansion of the MHC-I peptidome.

evidence.quote: | Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination |
| Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape |

claims.caveat: These antigen-presentation measurements come from preclinical mechanistic assays and may not generalize uniformly across all tumor models or human tumors.

claims.claim: Type I interferon signaling is a key mechanistic driver of the sensitization effect from intratumoral mRNA vaccination.

evidence.quote: | Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors |
- Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
1. Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: The causal role of interferon signaling is supported by blockade experiments in the tested systems, but the magnitude and safety of interferon-driven inflammation could differ by tumor type and clinical context.

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination increases PD-L1 pathway activity and is associated with higher intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density, supporting combination with checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: | PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable |
| Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change | 1.8x | 1.0x | Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy |
4. PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.

claims.caveat: Fold-changes in PD-L1 and CD8+ density do not alone establish clinical benefit; the relationship between these biomarkers and patient outcomes can vary across tumor types and treatment histories.

claims.claim: In a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients treated with ICIs, prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination was associated with improved survival.

evidence.quote: - Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.
| Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |
- The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.caveat: Because the human comparison is observational with variable vaccination timing, it cannot establish that vaccination caused better survival; unmeasured differences between groups may explain part or all of the association.

claims.claim: Control conditions indicate that vaccine-only, ICI-only, and non-mRNA particle controls do not reproduce the full sensitization effect seen with the intended intervention.

evidence.quote: - Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models.
- ICI-only treatment had limited activity in low-immunogenic baseline settings.
- Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.

claims.caveat: These null results are described at a high level and appear context-dependent (for example, in non-immunogenic or low-immunogenic settings), so they may not apply to all tumor models or clinical settings.
